subclusters.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on accumulation of unrepaired nuclear DNA damage, impaired repair pathways (NER, transcription-coupled repair), and genome instability driving aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Emphasizes age-related decline in nuclear DNA double-strand break repair capacity and chromatin structure changes affecting repair.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes oxidative nuclear DNA damage and error-prone NHEJ repair causing genome instability and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights accumulation of nuclear DNA damage, decline in repair, and genomic instability as central aging mechanisms.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on DNA damage accumulation in hematopoietic stem cells, ROS-induced nuclear DNA damage, and repair pathway failure.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes aging results from accumulation of unrepaired nuclear DNA lesions in somatic cells and tissue-specific repair capacity.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Fanconi anemia exemplifies genomic instability from defective nuclear DNA repair causing accelerated aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes age-related decline in nuclear DNA double-strand break repair efficiency and shift to error-prone repair pathways.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ERCC1-mediated nucleotide excision repair decline with age causing genomic instability and accelerated aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes DNA damage accumulation, DNA repair genes as longevity assurance, and trade-offs between cancer prevention and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on decline in base excision repair and NHEJ in aging neurons causing nuclear DNA damage accumulation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes age-dependent decline in nuclear DNA repair capacity, especially in neurons, leading to genomic instability.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Covers accumulation of nuclear DNA damage and mutations, decline in repair capacity, and extension to mitochondrial DNA damage.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights accumulation of nuclear DNA damage and correlation of repair efficiency with lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Nuclear DNA Repair Deficiency and Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on genetic instability from nuclear DNA damage, repair deficiency, telomere shortening, and epigenetic deregulation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: DNA Damage Repair-Associated Epigenetic Drift Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on DNA repair-induced chromatin remodeling and DNA methylation changes causing epigenetic drift during aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Defective Protein Genetic Programming Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes aging results from defects in genetically produced proteins regulating aging, with single defective proteins as master regulators.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Gene Damage Accumulation and Cellular Senescence Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Mathematical model of gene damage accumulation leading to loss of proliferative capacity and cell death thresholds.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: DNA Replication Initiation Decline Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on age-related decline in DNA polymerase alpha activity impairing DNA synthesis initiation and causing cellular senescence.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: DNA Synthesis Initiation (DSI) Depletion Theory of Programmed Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes finite number of DNA synthesis initiation loci act as a molecular clock controlling cellular senescence and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Oxidative Stress Signaling Decline Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes loss of oxidative stress tolerance due to reduced ERK and Akt kinase activities with aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: DNA Damage-Induced Metabolic Redesign Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: DNA damage causes transcription stress leading to ATP surplus, glycolysis inhibition, and rerouting glucose to antioxidant pathways.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Accumulation Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on stochastic accumulation of mtDNA mutations causing mitochondrial dysfunction and energetic decline with age.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Accumulation Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes mitochondrial genome mutations driving aging and age-related diseases via impaired mitochondrial function.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Accumulation Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights accumulation of mtDNA damage and decline in mitochondrial proliferation causing energy deficits and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Integrated Nuclear-Mitochondrial Genome Instability Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes interplay between nuclear and mitochondrial genome instability, p53 signaling, and mitochondrial quality control in aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Accumulation Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes resistance of mitochondrial DNA motifs to damage correlates with species lifespan, linking mtDNA stability to aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: DNA Damage Control System Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on endogenous DNA damage and cellular protective systems including repair, apoptosis, and immune surveillance modulated by low-dose radiation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Comprehensive Damage Repair and Rejuvenation Theory (SENS)
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes aging results from seven types of cellular damage including nuclear and mitochondrial DNA mutations, with potential for repair-based rejuvenation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Default-Executive Coupling Hypothesis of Aging (DECHA)
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes cognitive aging as a shift from fluid to crystallized cognition mediated by increased coupling between default and executive brain networks.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Default-Executive Coupling Hypothesis of Aging (DECHA)
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on increased default-executive network coupling underlying semanticized autobiographical memory and cognitive shifts in aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Default-Executive Coupling Hypothesis of Aging (DECHA)
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes reduced executive control and default network suppression with increased coupling as adaptive cognitive shift in older adults.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Stability Theory of Brain Aging
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on genetic stability and environmental influences on brain morphology changes during aging.
